data: The text is placed on the underside of the vessel arranged in a spiral.
Found in Imera, at the Temple D.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Parco Archeologico di Himera e Antiquarium
Excellent collection of archaeological material from the site of Himera and the surrounding area (in particular Settefrati and Cefalu) arranged according to find spot
Contrada Buonfornello - Termini Imerese (PA) On the hill above the temple
Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l'étude du vocabulaire grec colonial
L. Dubois, Inscriptions Grecques Dialectales de Sicile : Contribution à l’étude Du Vocabulaire Grec Colonial, CEFR 119 (Rome: Ecole française de Rome, 1989)
Carmina epigraphica graeca saeculorum VIII-V a. Chr. n. [vol. I] and ... saeculi IV a. Chr. n. [II]. «Texte und Kommentare», 12, 15. ol. I, nos. 1-465; II, nos. 466-901.

P.A. Hansen, Carmina Epigraphica Graeca Saeculorum VIII-V a. Chr. n. [Vol. I] and ... Saeculi IV a. Chr. n. [II]. «Texte Und Kommentare», 12, 15. Ol. I, Nos. 1-465; II, Nos. 466-901., 2 vols (Berlin, 1983)
Alcune iscrizioni inedite dall'area sacra e dall'abitato di Himera
M.T. Manni Piraino, ‘Alcune Iscrizioni Inedite Dall’area Sacra e Dall’abitato Di Himera’, Kokalos 20 (1974): 265–71
Ζε̄νὸς ἐριγδούποιο κόρε̄ι γλαυκο̄́πῑ Ἀθε̄́νε̄ι Θρίπυλος εὐξάμενος τε̄́νδ’ ἀνέθε̄κε θεᾶι
parco archeologico di himera e antiquarium

1Ζε̄νὸς ἐριγδούπ̣οιο κ̣όρε̄ι γλαυκο̄́πῑ Ἀ͡θε̄́νε̄ι
2Θρίπυλος εὐξάμεν̣ος τε̄́νδ’ ἀνέθε̄κε̣ θεᾶι

l.2 subscript

1ΖΕ̄ΝΟΣΕΡΙΓΔΟΥ.ΟΙΟ.ΟΡΕ̄ΙΓΛΑΥΚΟ̄ΠῙΑ͡ΘΕ̄ΝΕ̄Ι
2ΘΡΙΠΥΛΟΣΕΥΞΑΜΕ.ΟΣΤΕ̄ΝΔΑΝΕΘΕ̄Κ.ΘΕΑΙ

l.2 subscript

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Arena (IGASM 3)

English translation

To the bright-eyed Athena daughter of loud-thundering Zeus, Thripylos invoking dedicated this (kylix?) to the goddess.

Italian translation

Valentina Mignosa

Per Atena dagli occhi lucenti figlia di Zeus altitonante, Thripylos invocante ha dedicato questa (kylix?) alla dea.

commentary

Inscription incised in neat characters before firing on a base of a medium-sized vase. The inscription is a couplet of poetic inspiration whose first hemistich is the same as the beginning of v. 3 of the Homeric Hymn to Hera (Ζε̄νὸς ἐριγδούποιο). It is followed by another Homeric formula (γλαυκο̄́πῑ Ἀθε̄́νε̄ι) with a shortened form γλαυκο̄́πῑ rather than the recurring γλαυκῶπιν. The form κόρε̄ι has a vocalism that is attested in Euboea (cf. Bechtel 1921-1924, 74). τε̄́νδ(ε) could refer to κύλικα but could also indicate something else. It is interesting to note that a clay and headless figurine of Athena was found near the vase (Manni Piraino 1974, p. 266).
